webTitle: SAC Capital insider trading trial gets under way with jury selection

fields.standfirst:
• Prosecutors bill case as 'biggest insider trading deal in history'

• Mathew Martoma accused of orchestrating $276m scam
fields.body:
Jury selection begins on Tuesday in a case federal prosecutors are billing as the largest insider trading deal in US history.

Mathew Martoma, a former employee to SAC Capital, is accused of orchestrating a $276m scam that illegally profited from insider knowledge in a new Alzheimer’s drug. The former employee of the troubled SAC hedge fund has pleaded not guilty.

The trial will bring further pressure to bear on SAC and its billionaire founder Steven Cohen. Martoma’s prosecution is part of a larger, multi-year investigation into the hedge fund by federal agencies. Cohen and SAC have previously denied any wrongdoing in the case. The company declined to comment further.

The Manhattan trial is the 11th insider trading case brought by Preet Bharara, the US attorney for the southern district of New York. So far he has not lost an insider trading case and has secured 77 convictions.

In December another former SAC Capital employee, Michael Steinberg, was found guilty of insider trading in tech stocks including Dell. SAC Capital was fined $1.8bn last year after prosecutors accused the company of fostering a culture of insider trading "that was substantial, pervasive, and on a scale without known precedent".

Announcing charges against Martoma last year Bharara said the case was “on a scale that has no historical precedent”. The trial is expected to draw in Cohen, who has not been charged with any wrongdoing. He held a 20-minute conversation with Martoma shortly after he had allegedly been given insider information but has said he cannot recall what was discussed.

Martoma, 39, is accused of illegally trading on insider information he had gained on Elan and Wyeth, two drug firms working on an experimental Alzheimer's drug known as bapineuzumab.

Two doctors – Dr Sidney Gilman and Dr Joel Ross – hired by Elan to consult on a clinical drug trial are expected to testify that they supplied information to Martoma that the drug trials had run into difficulties.

Martoma and Gilman met on Saturday, 19 July 2008, according to prosecutors. When the stock markets opened again on 21 July, SAC began unwinding its holdings in the drug companies, betting their share prices would fall. The move earned SAC $276m in profits and avoided losses, prosecutors allege.

Martoma, free on a $5m bail, has been charged with one count of conspiracy to commit securities fraud and two counts of securities fraud. Each fraud count carries up to 20 years in prison.

webTitle: Morrisons dips as analysts caution on supermarket's trading

fields.standfirst: Barclays says company may find it hard to achieve positive fourth quarter sales
fields.body:
With investors still trying to pick the festive winners among the retailers, it is the turn of Morrisons to be feel the force of possible disappointment.

The supermarket, which reports later this month, is down 3.9p at 252.4p, following news from Aldi and Lidl that the discounters enjoyed a record Christmas trading period. Meanwhile Barclays - despite keeping an equal weight rating on the shares - has expressed some concerns about Morrisons' trading:

Our preliminary forecast assumed that Morrisons accelerates into December as it has done in past years, giving a like for like sales decline of between -2.3% and -2.8%. We are slightly concerned that Asda's apparent late surge – and the wider success of online – may have come partly at the expense of Morrison and therefore set our forecast at the bottom of this range, ie -2.8%.
Morrisons stated in November that "we will move into positive like-for-like sales growth in the fourth quarter". We very much doubt that Morrisons' Christmas trading will deliver positive like for like, but the fourth quarter overall will benefit from the very weak comparisons in the final few weeks of the quarter. However, if our Christmas forecast is broadly correct then Morrisons may find it harder than it expected in November to deliver a positive like for like sales number for the fourth quarter – and there is a real risk that the company will have to step back from this commitment when it reports on 20 January.

Meanwhile Barclays repeated its underweight recommendation on Morrisons' online partner Ocado, up 4p at 459.3p.

Elsewhere Burberry is down 29p at £14.75. Again Barclays has an equal weight rating but with an element of caution:

Burberry third quarter sales need to show strong comparable sales growth (Barclays +8%) to retain confidence in the second half forecasts. These looked stretched following its downgrade of the Beauty earnings guidance from £25m to £10m at the end of the first half. This suggests £41m of underlying earnings is required in the second half to achieve our forecasts (adjusting for profit related pay, foreign exchange and Beauty) from just £119m of organic sales growth (a 34% conversion), and even higher if lower yielding space growth is taken into consideration which is a real test of its pay as you go strategy. Given the concerns over management changes, Japan and the Beauty contract in a sector that is losing appeal to the European based cyclical stocks, we are happy to retain the equal weight rating and 1,700p price target ahead of the third quarter retail sales on 15 January.

webTitle: UK car sales at highest since onset of financial crisis

fields.bodyText: UK car sales soared to their highest level since 2007 last year, fuelled by growing consumer confidence, cheap finance deals and payouts over PPI mis-selling. However, the sales glut brought a warning that secondhand car prices could slump within the next two years as the market is flooded with vehicles. The number of new cars sold jumped nearly 11% to 2.26m in 2013, the highest level since the onset of the financial crisis, according to the figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT). It was equivalent to 600 more cars sold a day in 2013 compared with 2012, and bucked the trend across much of Europe where sales have been falling. UK sales rose by almost a quarter to 152,918 in December alone. Mike Hawes, the SMMT's chief executive, said the car market had been "a bright spot" in the UK economy, helped by cheap finance deals which account for around three-quarters of transactions. He said it was difficult to measure the precise impact of Payment Protection Insurance compensation on the car industry, but that average payouts of £3,000 were having an impact: "It's enough to put a deposit down on a car." John Leech, head of automotive at consulting group KPMG, said that while cheap credit had been great for driving sales, it could store up problems for the used-car market "a year or two from now". Leech said there was a danger of an oversupply of used cars building up as consumers opt to return their cars at the end of their three-year personal car plan (PCP) deals. "Car dealers now sell finance with the car where half the price is paid over 36 months and the remaining half is cleared by a bullet payment at the end of the three years. This has been great for new car sales as consumers choose to take a new car on another PCP rather than pay the bullet. The danger for car manufacturers and used car dealers is that the supply of three-year-old cars is starting to ramp up and, maybe in a year or two from now, will exceed demand leading to a potential residual value price crash and an increased risk of loan default by consumers," he said. The SMMT predicted a slowing of growth in new car sales to 1% in 2014, as the rebound in demand from the lows during the recession fades. A breakdown of the figures showed the strongest growth in 2013 due to private buyers, which rose nearly 20% as consumers felt more confident amid economic growth and falling unemployment and were encouraged by attractive promotions. The Ford Fiesta was the best-selling new car in the UK last year, followed by the Ford Focus, Vauxhall Corsa, Vauxhall Astra and Volkswagen Golf. The SMMT said British buying patterns were shifting towards smaller, more fuel-efficient models, with "supermini" vehicles taking the largest market share of 35.9% in 2013. Registrations of hybrid and plug-in cars rose 20.5% to 32,715 vehicles. Prime Minister David Cameron tweeted that the 2013 figures were an example of the growing UK economy: "5 key measures of manufacturing at all-time high & UK car sales top pre-2007 levels. See how we're growing UK economy." UK demand has consistently outperformed the rest of Europe where car sales have been falling. Spain was the only other major market to register a growth in sales last year, with volumes up 2.1%, driven by a scrappage scheme. The German, French and Italian markets all shrank. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight: "The motor industry will be hoping that the recent improvement in UK economic activity is sustained and extended, and that this underpins consumer and business confidence, and their willingness to splash out on new cars." webTitle: Pawnbroker H&T on hunt for acquisitions

fields.standfirst: Britain's biggest pawnbroker said its business was hit by the 29% fall in the price of gold last year
fields.body:
Pawnbroker H&T said it was looking to make acquisitions in the embattled sector as it reported trading in line with market expectations.

Britain's biggest pawnbroker said its business was hit by the 29% fall in the price of gold last year. Its pledge book of items on which loans were made was down 14.5% to £44.1m at the end of December because of increased competition and lower lending rates.

But a switch from selling gold for scrap to pushing retail sales resulted in fourth-quarter like-for-like sales rising 56% on the prior year – a turnaround from sales dropping 12% in the first quarter.

Pawnbrokers have been hit by the plunge in the market price of gold after investors turned away from low-risk investments.

Increased stability in the eurozone and receding fears of runaway inflation triggered a withdrawal from gold, which investors often turn to during market turmoil.

H&T cut back on its gold buying operations in time to avoid disaster but its rival Albemarle & Bond is battling to avoid bankruptcy.

H&T could be in the running for parts of Albemarle & Bond if the latter business is broken up, and will consider snapping up smaller pawnbroking operations that are struggling. H&T, which has 190 stores, also expects to close a handful of less profitable branches.

In its trading update, the firm said: "The current challenging market will accelerate the industry consolidation and rationalisation that we believe is necessary in the short term.

"It is likely that H&T will close a small number of non-contributing stores in 2014 and at the same time will look to acquire profitable pawnbroking opportunities."

H&T's share price has halved in the past year but the shares were up 3.3% to 150p in morning trading.

Analysts at Numis said: "Given the backdrop, we see this as a relatively reassuring update."

webTitle: Royal Mail slips as broker says it is time to sell

fields.standfirst: Cantor Fitzgerald says valuation is no longer compelling after spectacular rise
fields.body:
Royal Mail has, obviously, had a stellar run since its flotation at 330p in October.

It hit a peak of 607p - prompting much talk of the government selling it off too cheaply - but could it now be time to sell?

That is the view of analyst Robin Byde at Cantor Fitzgerald, who has begun coverage of the group with a sell recommendation and target price of 500p. He said:

Royal Mail has made good progress on restructuring but still faces significant challenges. It has powerful brands, an unrivalled network in the UK and with GLS a leading pan-European parcel operator. However, core letter volumes continue to decline sharply and many other operators are fighting for share in the packets & parcels market.
Costs are being contained and productivity is rising but Royal Mail still needs to invest heavily in automation to lift service quality, efficiency and margins. The many uncertainties around medium-term growth, costs-of-change and capex are reflected in the broad range of forecasts in the market. Following its spectacular post-IPO performance, Royal Mail's valuation and dividend yield are no longer compelling. It is trading on a 2014 estimated PE of 14.7 times versus the European logistics sector on 15.2 times and other postal companies on 12 times. Our 2014 annualised dividend yield, at 3.2%, is below the wider FTSE 100, yielding 3.8%.

Royal Mail shares are currently down 6p at 566p.

webTitle: FTSE lifted by bank shares but water companies fall on fading deal hopes

fields.standfirst: JP Morgan says mergers unlikely in water sector due to continuing regulatory risk
fields.body:
Markets are edging higher, helped by a rise in banking shares on the positive prospects for the UK economy in 2014.

But water companies are falling as fast as the rain after analysts at JP Morgan downplayed the prospects of deals in the sector. The bank said:

We believe that Ofwat's decision to alter the price review timetable and announce the key financial parameters on January 27 is likely to herald a lower allowed weighted average cost of capital than the companies requested in their business plans.
We also see M&A this year as unlikely given the degree of regulatory risk, with Ofwat's final determinations not due until December 2014. We have therefore excluded any M&A premia from our price targets for all three quoted water companies.

The bank downgraded Severn Trent, down 38p to £16.66, from neutral to underweight and cut its price target from £16.80 to £15.35.

It put a neutral rating on United Utilities, 2p lower at 670.5p, but lowered its target from 750p to 735p.

But it kept an overweight rating on Pennon, up 3.5p at 667.5p, albeit reducing its target from 745p to 700p.

On a more positive note, Lloyds Banking Group is leading the way, up 1.23p at 81.34p, while HSBC was 6.9p better at 666.9p.

Marks & Spencer has recovered some of its recent falls ahead of its trading update on Thursday, adding 6.1p to 446.4p.

Overall the FTSE 100 has added 16.05 points to 6746.78, ahead of a series of key economic releases later in the week, including the latest Bank of England and European Central Bank meetings and US non-farm payroll numbers. The US Senate vote in favour of Janet Yellen's appointment as chair of the Federal Reserve also helped sentiment. David Madden, market analyst at IG, said:

Yellen's confirmation as the head of the US central bank has put the markets at ease. The new chairwoman is a safe pair of hands and, although she will not allow the markets to dictate her policies, she is unlikely to do anything too drastic in the early stages of her leadership.

Elsewhere ITV has added 2p to 199.7p as Jefferies moved from hold to buy with a price target lifted from 110p to 231p. It said:

Our review of ITV's progress through the transformation plan identifies clear progress in a number of areas and some work yet to be done, particularly with regard to platform strategy. That said, we also see the UK linear television advertising market on the mend and ITV the key beneficiary here. In addition, the emergence of BT Sport perhaps encourages more imaginative M&A in the sector than has been the case traditionally.

webTitle: Centrica's finance director quits

fields.standfirst: Nick Luff's departure to Reed Elsevier leaves British Gas owner looking for replacement at time of turmoil for energy industry
fields.body:
Centrica's finance director is quitting the company to join Reed Elsevier, leaving the British Gas owner looking for a replacement at a time of turmoil for the energy industry.

Nick Luff will join the Anglo-Dutch publisher and information provider when Centrica has found a successor. Centrica said it had already begun the search.

Luff joined Centrica in 2007, soon after Sam Laidlaw was appointed chief executive .

Laidlaw said: "I will miss Nick's valuable input to my team and I would like to thank him for his ongoing support over the coming months. I know that I speak on behalf of everyone at Centrica in wishing him well in this next chapter of his career."

Luff's departure leaves Centrica looking for a new finance director as the group grapples with a political storm over household energy bills ahead of the 2015 election. Centrica is also the preferred bidder to take control of Bord Gáis Energy, the Irish state-owned energy board.

The move will take Luff from his politically charged role to the world of providing data for lawyers and scientists.

Centrica said Luff was leaving for a "new challenge" in a different industry. He will be paid his salary and benefits during his notice period and unvested share awards will lapse when he leaves.

Before joining Centrica, Luff worked at P&O, the shipping group with joint operations between the UK and the Netherlands.

Erik Engstrom, Reed Elsevier's chief executive, said: "I am pleased to have Nick join the team. His many years of experience as finance director of a [top 30 FTSE 100] company, combined with his involvement in dual UK/US and Netherlands-based listings, make him a great fit for Reed Elsevier."

Luff will take over from Duncan Palmer, who announced in September he was leaving Reed Elsevier to return to the US for family reasons. Both Centrica and Reed Elsevier said there would be handover periods between their new and old finance chiefs.

Centrica shares fell 0.76% to 339.9p in early morning trading.

webTitle: Sales rise at Topps Tiles and Dunelm

fields.standfirst: Both retailers – whose fortunes are linked to the housing market – unveil upbeat quarterly trading figures
fields.body:
Topps Tiles and Dunelm, two retailers whose fortunes are linked to the housing market, have unveiled upbeat trading figures.

Revenue at Topps, which sells tiles and flooring from 328 stores, rose by 9.3% in the first quarter of its financial year excluding new branches.

At Dunelm, the homewares specialist, like-for-like sales increased by 2.9% in the second quarter after a decline in the first three months of its financial year.

Matthew Williams, Topps' chief executive, said: "Topps traded strongly over the first quarter, with an acceleration in like-for-like sales growth over the final month of the period.

"Whilst we are encouraged by this and remain optimistic about prospects for 2014, at this early stage in the year we remain cautious of projecting forward this level of performance. Trading over the second quarter will be key in this regard."

Dunelm said sales recovered in the final three months of 2013 after unusually warm weather kept shoppers out of its stores in the summer. That recovery was helped by its move into TV advertising.

First-half like-for-like sales fell 0.9% but sales including new stores rose 4.8%. The group expects first-half pre-tax profit to be about £61.5m, up from £59.8m the year before.

Nick Wharton, Dunelm's chief executive, said: "With a strengthening customer proposition, increasing brand awareness, a significant new store growth opportunity and an exciting multichannel agenda in place, the board remains confident in the long-term growth prospects for the business."

Topps and Dunelm are the latest retailers to unveil sales figures for the period covering Christmas. Hopes of bumper trading supported by rising consumer confidence have not materialised and retailers' fortunes are expected to differ sharply.

Last week Next announced forecast-beating sales but Debenhams was forced to issue a profit warning following deep pre-Christmas discounting.

Dunelm's founder, Bill Adderley, was revealed in October as the biggest private shareholder in Marks & Spencer with a 3% stake. M&S, which is expected to have had poor Christmas trading, is set to update the market on Thursday.

webTitle: Investigations launched into Co-op Bank's £1.5bn capital shortfall

fields.bodyText: Former directors of the Co-operative Bank face fines and bans from the financial services industry after two more investigations into the events leading up to its £1.5bn bailout were announced . The Bank of England's regulation arm, the Prudential Regulation Authority, and the City regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority, made formal announcements of enforcement investigations into the events that led to a £1.5bn capital shortfall being revealed last June. The investigations could take months to complete and mean that an independent review commissioned by George Osborne in November will be delayed until decisions are made about whether to take any action against the bank and its former management. Investigations into other bank problems have taken years. The outcome of an investigation into the rescue of HBOS by Lloyds TSB in September 2008 is not expected to be published until this summer while the report into Royal Bank of Scotland was published three years after its taxpayer bailout. The investigations may find no personal wrongdoing. For instance, no individual at RBS was found to be legally responsible for its near collapse while at HBOS only former banker Peter Cummings has been fined £500,000 and banned from working in the City. After a £1.5bn capital shortfall was identified by the PRA, the Co-op bank had to be rescued by bondholders – including US hedge funds and as a result the Co-operative Group of supermarkets, pharmacies and funeral homes has been left owning just 30% of the bank. A stockmarket flotation of the bank is possible this year and the new management said they were working with the regulators. "The new management team had to rectify the difficult and complex issues that they have inherited," the bank said. webTitle: Businesses warn lending curbs will hit recovery

fields.standfirst: British Chambers of Commerce said restrictions on bank lending to small and medium-sized businesses will hit growth
fields.body:
Britain's rapid recovery will be hampered in 2014 unless the government acts to encourage corporate lending, a leading business group warns on Tuesday.

The British Chambers of Commerce said growth this year will remain steady, but restrictions on lending to small and medium-sized businesses will restrict the pace of expansion.

The warning came as figures showed that the services sector maintained its year-long surge in output during December. The Markit/CIPS purchasing managers index (PMI) was a little weaker than the previous month and the pace of growth was slowest since June. But this still outstripped the eurozone average and especially France, which suffered a second successive month of falling services output – and at an accelerating rate.

According to the BCC, five key measures of manufacturing were at an all-time high, allaying fears towards the end of last year that the growth spurt in manufacturing was temporary. Domestic orders, employment, employment expectations, turnover confidence and profitability confidence were all performing well alongside export sales and export orders.

John Longworth, director general of the BCC, said it was "pleasing that the spurt in manufacturing has proven not to be a fluke, which demonstrates the dynamism of our small, high-value, manufacturing sector".

But he cautioned against complacency after the survey found that restrictions on cashflow and a lack of access to credit was restricting investment in new plant and machinery.

Suren Thiru, a UK economist at the BCC, said: "When we speak to members they say the big issue is the lack of access to finance and the detrimental impact investment will have on cashflows. It is clear there are still significant issues around bank lending," he said.

The Markit/CIPS PMI headline business activity index registered a level of 58.8, down from 60 in November, for the UK, compared with a eurozone average of 52.1. The eurozone has benefited from recoveries in Spain and Ireland while France has struggled, down to a six-month low of 47.8 from 48.5. A figure above 50 shows expansion.

Markit said the UK's growth was driven by a jump in new business, which has risen continuously throughout 2013. It said the average growth rate in the final quarter of the year was the best in the survey history, despite December registering the weakest increase in new work for three months.

Chris Williamson, Markit's chief economist, said: "Service providers ended 2013 in a buoyant mood. Although growth of business activity slowed, it has come down from super-strong levels and the pace of expansion remains elevated. If the buoyancy of the surveys in the fourth quarter is borne out by the official data, the economy will have grown by 1.9% over the course of 2013, which would be the best we've seen since 2007."

Computing and IT, transport and communication, financial services, and business-to-business services showed the strongest growth. The car industry also maintained its strong performance, in contrast with the ailing French car business, which has only recently steadied after a long period of cuts to production and job layoffs.
